summary: The appellant, a prison warder, was convicted of stealing old corrugated iron sheets belonging to the government. On appeal, the West Africa Court of Appeal quashed the conviction, holding that the appellant acted in good faith and reasonably believed the materials had been abandoned by the government. The court emphasized that abandoned property cannot be stolen, and thus there was no mens rea. Additionally, the trial judge misdirected himself by applying an incorrect legal test for theft under Section 383 of the Criminal Code and failed to consider the appellant's belief regarding abandonment, constituting a further misdirection.
rationaleHighlights: Appellant took abandoned government property in good faith
No mens rea established due to reasonable belief in abandonment
Ownership abandonment negates capacity for theft
Trial judge erred in legal test for stealing
Failure to direct jury on accused's belief was misdirection
